Sorry if this topic has already been brought up, which I'm sure it has considering that's the forum it's in. I'm new. Anyway, I'm always interested in looking at different perspectives. What's your philosophy on life? Or do you even have one?

As I get older and say goodbye to relatives and friends it makes me think nothing is more important than the relationships we have with our family and friends. Forget about jobs, money, material goods; none of these things matter if you don't have loved ones to share them with. My brother's wife passed away this week, she was 39 years old, I think it reminded all of us how much we need each other.

My brother's wife passed away this week, she was 39 years old, I think it reminded all of us how much we need each other.

 Sorry to hear about the loss. I know my sisters-in-law are dear to me as sisters and have been an asset to our family. I can see how losing one could bring pain.
 
 I agree, jskufan. I think, that above all, we should love one another. No, it's not that melodramatic, soap opera, clingy type, but that original, sincere love.
 
 Time takes its toll on those who are selfish and it shows in so many different ways. There is definitely a thin line between love and hate, but we can choose which side of that line we reside.
 
 My philosophy is just that: To love. All else falls into place.

Jskufan & Big Orn (& conphyoozed1),
 I agree with you both.
 Everyone here knows my beliefs in God, but, whether one believes in God, or not, I think we can all agree that "Love" is the most important thing.
 
 For those who are interested, here is what Jesus said about it:
 Mark 12:29,
 "The most important commandment is this: 'Hear, O Israel! The Lord our God is the one and only Lord. And you must love the Lord your God with all your heart, all your soul, all your mind, and all your strength.' The second is equally important: 'Love your neighbor as yourself.' No other commandment is greater than these."
 
 Sandy

 
 Hello, Sandycane.
 I have a read a few of your posts and can say that I agree with most of what you say - even though we might be on different levels. Of course that is neither good or bad.
 Just thought I'd let you know where I stand.

 I just stumbled into this thread while wandering around looking for trouble.
 Sorry to hear about your sister-in-law. It's tough enough when someone much older dies, but increasingly so when they're young.
 My condolences. I'll put her in my prayers.

Sorry if this topic has already been brought up, which I'm sure it has considering that's the forum it's in. I'm new. Anyway, I'm always interested in looking at different perspectives. What's your philosophy on life? Or do you even have one?

 
 I believe in balance. I've balanced my career with my family and have found that, while it may have hurt my career to NOT have spend as much time at the office as some of my associates, I have always thought that family came first.
 No one ever had the following inscription on their tombstone:
  I wish that I had spent more time at the office.

I've also found that balance between the issues I prefer to focus on in life provides me with satisfaction and sustains personal growth. Although faster horses, younger women and older whiskey was also fun in my younger years as a balance to the corporate pressure cooker and extensive travel.

I have no specific philosophy. I don't like labels. I believe that they limit you.
 
 Although I'm currently researching objectivism. (Related to individualism)

Worldwide political realism. It should be applied to all aspects of life. When something no longer becomes benneficiary, lose it. No this is not meant in a heartless way, but more of an objective way to look at things.

 I have no one philosophy....but i do strongly believe that if all followed the big 10, we would be a better world. I think that old saying is probably true, "Lifes a :xcensored and then you die". I say, live hard and fast cuz it's over in a flash! One can never give or get enough love. emoticon_xangel

I have no one philosophy....but i do strongly believe that if all followed the big 10, we would be a better world. I think that old saying is probably true, "Lifes a :xcensored and then you die". I say, live hard and fast cuz it's over in a flash! One can never give or get enough love. emoticon_xangel

 
 You mention we die...seemingly fast.
 You also mention we have needs that seem to be unrealistic...wanting too much and not having enough time.
 
 I agree in a way with this.
 
 But the question I have is, would it be a good goal to end these things you dislike about life? I.e. pursue changing what you feel is wrong with the world?
 Lifespan, at least the "natural" death from disease or old age, is not theoretically something that has to happen. Nor is our insatiable for desire for certain things. I didn't ask for a short life span or out of control mental functions...I'm not sure why I should be forced to sit back and take it.
 
 -Mach

The one key thing my dad taught me is that almost everything should be done in moderation....
 
 Eating...
 Drinking....
 Sleeping...
 Religion...
 Sex....
 
 I think those are the big five really.......but you can apply it to just about anything.....
 
 I also have come to realize the value of knowledge and life on this earth. Regardless of the afterlife.....I will try my best to live each day to the fullest...not in some cheesey cliche way...but actually doing it...at least doing one good thing a day.....life is priceless...this very moment we now possess ..and some of the memories I have I wouldn't trade it for all the money in the world...
 
 Life is definitely to short....that's why I'm kind to everyone usually....and try my best to be a decent person....

It's tough to come up with a simple philosophy for all of life, but this is what I tell my kids:
 
 There is only one thing that really scares me; and that is this:
 I hope that when I'm old (older now might be more appropriate), I never catch myself sitting in my rocker on the porch and saying "I wish I had _____(fill in the blank)."

 Enjoy the company of your family and friends while you can. Life would be pretty dull if you had all the riches in the world but no family or friends, eh?
 
 

 I agree, jskufan. I think, that above all, we should love one another. No, it's not that melodramatic, soap opera, clingy type, but that original, sincere love.

 Yes, humans are obviously meant to interact, love (sincerely), and take care of one another.
 
 
My philosophy is just that: To love. All else falls into place.

 Love between people is very important to our well-being. Like Sandycane said, love is an integral part to Jesus's teachings.
 
 As for my philosophy of life, I don't specifically have one besides that we were put here to fellowship with one another and to glorify God...
With regard to people I think always treat others as you would hope to be treated yourself.

Although I'm currently researching objectivism. (Related to individualism)

 
 As in Randroid Objectivism? The Virtue of Selfishness? The lady who was so wank that she opted not to send her work to peer review, rather to popular consumption? 
 
 Rand's a good author of fiction, but a moral philospher, she is not, imo. Some things she says are ok, but she's largely crazy and 2 dimensional.

As in Randroid Objectivism? The Virtue of Selfishness? The lady who was so wank that she opted not to send her work to peer review, rather to popular consumption? 
 
 Rand's a good author of fiction, but a moral philospher, she is not, imo. Some things she says are ok, but she's largely crazy and 2 dimensional.

 
 Yes, but you're attacking the person, not the philosophy, what shall we make of that?
 
 -Mach

Yes, but you're attacking the person, not the philosophy, what shall we make of that?
 

 
 
 While Rand is a good author, she isn't a good Philosopher. SHe is largely guilty of what academics calls "pseudo-phillophy" and "pseudo-morality." Rand, instead of putting her ideas into a credible peer reviewed journal, decided to cop-out and form her own little clan of pseduo-philosophers, totally bypassing legimiate academics.
 
 Instead of putting her ideas formally in journals for review, she put them into a series of entertaining, yet woefully 2 dimentional characters in books, specifically catering to the mass public, not academic channels.
 
 She has the audacity to call the most credible philosophers of history and time-tested scholars, XXXXXX and fools, which is silly, considering that she can hardly think logically herself. Her books grossly distort any opposition to make everyone seem stupid,and her philosophy seem fantastic.
 
 
 The entire basis of her philsophy is largely a combination of Ethical egoism, which is hardly an ethical philsophy insomuch that college curriculums rarely cover it--They cover ethical relativism more than that, it's so pathetic, and Rights-Based ethics.
 
 Rights, while very good and in many cases, Utilitarian, do not stand up on their own. Rights can, however, stem from Moral DUties, but of course she ignores any of this and calls everyone else imbeciles.
 She and her followers are largely a cult. and Rand is its messiah.
 
 
 The majority of all educated, credible scholars and philsophers agree that she's intellecutally dishonest, non-credible, and bogus.
 
 Randroids are largely among the uneducated, the easily fooled.
 She is batshitt insane. 
 
 The idea that she named her Philosophy "objectivism" is hilarious irony, since it's far from "objective." She even goes so far as to state a "perfect" form of Art, and that only "her" philsophy is the right way. Not only is there a right and wrong morality, there is a right and wrong to everything, according to one of her books--I believe her book on art and asthetics.
 
 
 Her philosophy, since it was taken over by Supreme Overlord Peikoff, has gotten even worse. It is completely impervious to change or alteration, and anyone who has any differences of opinion or modifications is signaled out and exiled: for example, take a student and former ARI member, Kelly. 
 
 Kelly was kicked out of the organization for trying to fix the stagnation of Objectivism, saying it ought to be an open system. INstead of adapting, it became like a religion--a closed system, as Peikoff once said. There is to be no change, for Objectivism is the "truth." Which is silly.
 
 The antagonists are usually weak, pathetic, full of uncertainty, and lacking in imagination and talent. In addition, the novels are alleged to contain errors or omissions in terms of the reality of social interactions, economics, technology, and history.

my philosiphy is roughly that of a disillusioned idealist: i started with so much hope for what we could achieve when i was younger, then i grew and had more experiences with human nature, and realized how screwed we really are. now its all just a strange mix of contempt, pity, and an odd nostalgia for when i was stupid too. as far as i'm concerned, were a bunch of ****ed-over apes sitting on a big floating rock, arguing about which ape controls more dirt and which has seen more 'invisible apes'. great for home entertainment-if you like the same show re-running with a different cast every week, like a bad reality tv show.

I dont have one but I'd like to have one...
 
 One of the reasons I like these types of forums is to experience different opinions, and to find topics I could further research.
 
 It seems a cycle though... I find a topic, it seems interesting, it even inspires me to an extent, I start to internalise the philosophy because I feel theres 'truth 'in it. A period of time later when again researching I find critiscism or out right hostility to the philosphy in question. Some of the critiscisms my rational brain decides might have a point so I'm once again thrown into disarray - obviously the philosophy isn't *the* philosophy and so the cycle continues...
 
 Sometimes I actually wish for blind faith in some religion or philosphy because this 'cycle' I talk about gets me down...
 
 Anyone empathise with what I'm talking about and or over come 'the cycle'?

I dont have one but I'd like to have one...

 It seems a cycle though... I find a topic, it seems interesting, it even inspires me to an extent, I start to internalise the philosophy because I feel theres 'truth 'in it. A period of time later when again researching I find critiscism or out right hostility to the philosphy in question. Some of the critiscisms my rational brain decides might have a point so I'm once again thrown into disarray - obviously the philosophy isn't *the* philosophy and so the cycle continues...
 
 Sometimes I actually wish for blind faith in some religion or philosphy because this 'cycle' I talk about gets me down...
 
 Anyone empathise with what I'm talking about and or over come 'the cycle'?

 With the obvious exception of religious enthusiasts who (if they're Christians) have the authority of the scriptures, revelations, etc., to guide them in the search for "answers" to the deep questions of life, atheists and such like can trust only in their reasoning powers to decide questions of what "ought" to be done, how one "ought" to live and so on. A person with a strong religious faith doesn't face moral and philosophical dilemmas in that bleak ambiguity which non-believers experience.
 
 For the thoughtful people (a minority) who bother to think about the problems of philosophy, the state of mental flux or cycle of questioning that you refer to, is probably quite regular. Only a few people, I guess, have a fully worked out philosophical standpoint from which they can survey the rest of humanity with objectivity and impunity. I'm not even sure such a detached vision is desirable. 
 
 I would include myself among the community of "searchers" who never find what they're looking for but content themselves with insights here and there - a bit like oases in a desert of uncertainty.

I would include myself among the community of "searchers" who never find what they're looking for but content themselves with insights here and there - a bit like oases in a desert of uncertainty.

 
 Seems a sad state of affairs to be honest with you... :(
 
 Is it a 'curse' or a 'gift' to be a 'searcher'?
 
 Some of us may look down on the those with faith or the 'happily ignorant' but it seems to me they enjoy a kind of 'peace of mind' that I propose not many 'searchers' like us ever manage.
 
 Perhaps I'm wrong though with my comments and someone will respond to my original post claming they've over come 'the cycle'.

Perhaps I'm wrong though with my comments and someone will respond to my original post claming they've over come 'the cycle'.

 
 i always strived for the purpose or meaning of life. the answers i've found for myself are:
 
 1.) life itself is meaningless 
 2.) everyone can give his life a meaning
 
 i can't claim this to be objective but it is true for me. but the real question is should i accept this meaningless life and wait until i die or should i give it a meaning knowing that this is only an illusion? can you go back into the matrix if you know the truth?

I totally agree with you, Wraith - both your posts. Hence my name. I wish I could say something wise or comforting, but I'm just another searcher. That's why I'm here. Not that it'll give me any answers, though I wish it could, but it's definitely put some interesting ideas in my mind.

i always strived for the purpose or meaning of life. the answers i've found for myself are:
 
 1.) life itself is meaningless
 2.) everyone can give his life a meaning
 
 i can't claim this to be objective but it is true for me. but the real question is should i accept this meaningless life and wait until i die or should i give it a meaning knowing that this is only an illusion? can you go back into the matrix if you know the truth?

 
 I certainly 'feel' gaining knowledge of the 'objective reality' to bring my 'subjective reality' closer to the 'truth' is a personal 'purpose of life' I've given to myself. To what end I give myself this purpose remains unclear - some days it feels like an amusing hobby others a life consuming obsession...
 
 I certainly don't feel you can re-enter the matrix if you find yourself not liking 'the real world' hence why us 'searchers' end up on sites like this - we can't go back to 'ignorance', the only way to escape our need for the *true* philosophy is to find it!
 
 
 I totally agree with you, Wraith - both your posts. Hence my name. I wish I could say something wise or comforting, but I'm just another searcher. That's why I'm here. Not that it'll give me any answers, though I wish it could, but it's definitely put some interesting ideas in my mind.

 
 Well, in a selfish way I'm glad I'm not the only one. ;)

Wraith if you are interested in the "search" for truth and the act of questioning to reach it may I recommend Søren Kierekgaard's "Concept of Irony", specifically the early portions (say first 120 pages) that deal with Socratic Irony. As well as Nietzsche's "Birth of Tragedy" (preface and aphorisms 12- 15) as well as Nietzsche's "Twilight of the Idols" 
 
 Of course you should read some Plato first, specifically the Apology, Phaedo, Republic, & Symposium. I think you will find some answers within these tomes. At very least you will find a new perspective on Philosophy.

newbie here; 
 
 I find it interesting how many people answer with some version of religion, or "attitude" to life, or one or another modus vivendi
 
 philosophy is not religion, although I acknowledge there is a philosophy OF religion (it's called Theology, i think). And, imo, Philosophy is much more more than an attitude. It helps me arrive at a way of living, but hardly comprises it.
 
 for the record, I'm a Cartesian; cogito ergo sum were the last words to make sense in the western philosophic tradition, imo 
 
 Philosophy is a serious discourse with a long and beautiful history.

While Rand is a good author, she isn't a good Philosopher. SHe is largely guilty of what academics calls "pseudo-philosophy" and "pseudo-morality." Rand, instead of putting her ideas into a credible peer reviewed journal, decided to cop-out and form her own little clan of pseduo-philosophers, totally bypassing legimiate academics. ...
 

 
 Your post is mostly ridicule  and appeal to authority. Peer-review? LMAO! Ethics is not something handed down to us by academic authorities (or supernatural authorities for that matter). Frankly, I'm glad Rand was a public intellectual engaged in moral discourse with her fellow citizens. 
 
 Rand has many important things to say. Sometimes I agree; sometimes I dont'. But I give her credit where credit is due. I suggest people read her and judge for themselves. Don't wait for peer-review before living your life! LOL.

newbie here; 
 
 
 for the record, I'm a Cartesian; cogito ergo sum were the last words to make sense in the western philosophic tradition, imo 
 
 Philosophy is a serious discourse with a long and beautiful history.
 
 Is this a serious forum or just the usual bunch of 1/2 (if that) educated American know nothings with typing skills and time on their hands?

 
 Your confident declaration that - "the last words to make sense in the western philosophic tradition" etc. - is a trifle premature don't you think, since Descartes died in 1650 ? 
 
 The continental rationalism exemplified by Descartes (and perhaps Spinoza) by no means contains the last words to make philosophic sense. Have you considered the British empiricist approach of Bacon, Locke, and Hume (among others) - who asserted that knowledge is a product of experiment and experience, and is thus subject to amendment ? This philosophic tradition is much better adapted to our post-Enlightenment "age of science".
 
 On the question of know nothings with time on their hands etc. - I think, if you stick around, you'll find plenty of serious well-informed people on this forum, and perhaps even a few scholars. (This assumes that you won't jump to negative conclusions on the basis of a brief acquaintance).

 Thanks for your thoughtful reply. 
 
 Renes Descartes: French philosopher of the Enlightenment. IMO, as good a place as any to mark the jumping of place where rationalism separated from theist (religious) medeival philosophic tradition.
 
 He was arguably the first existentialist....the tradition I most align with personally.
 
 cogito ergo sum was his famous quote (in Latin). translation: "I think therefore I am"
 
 This was his answer to the fundamental question of ontology (existence); i.e. "How do I know I exist?" I don't think he ever got around to the 2nd question of ontology: Why do I exist?
 
 I just said it was "last words to make sense......., to be a smartass and because much of what follows in the Continental Phil. tradition is SO complicated and arcane..(including Kant, imo)..few ever summed up their though so succintly as did Renes.
 
 Descartes was also famous as the author of the Mind/Body problem, usually referred to as dualism.
 
 Yes, I see from the posts this looks like a good place....i was afraid it might be over run by bible thumpers, like so much else these days.
 
 cheers...
